metadata.case_name: Pannalal Binjraj & Ors. v. Union of India

facts.text: Petitioners Nos. 97 and 97A of 1956: Petitioners Pannalal Binjraj (oil mill owners, merchants, commission agents at Sahibganj, branch at Calcutta) and R.B. Jamuna Das Chowdhury (Karta of HUF). Assessed by ITO Special Circle Patna before 28-9-1954. CBR transferred cases to ITO Central Circle XI Calcutta on 28-9-1954, then to ITO Central Circle VI Delhi on 22-1-1955 and 12-7-1955. Subsequent proceedings including assessments and penalty for non-payment challenged.

Petition No. 44 of 1956: Shri A.L. Sud, sole proprietor of Amritlal Sud Construction, resided in Calcutta since 1948, originally from Hoshiarpur. Assessed by ITO Special Survey Circle VII Calcutta before 29-6-1955. CBR transferred case to ITO Special Circle Ambala on 29-6-1955. Continued proceedings and assessments for 1946-47, 1947-48 under s.23(4).

Petition No. 85 of 1956: Messrs. Bhagwan Das Sud Sons, merchants Hoshiarpur. Case transferred by CIT to ITO Special Circle Ambala. Reopened assessments 1944-45 to 1950-51, completed for 1947-48, 1950-51, 1951-52. A.L. Sud member of this HUF.

Amritsar group (Petitions 86,87,88,111,112,158 of 1956): Sardar Gurdial Singh, Dr. Sarmukh Singh, S. Ram Singh, S. Narain Singh (directors of Hindustan Embroidery Mills Pvt Ltd at Chheharta near Amritsar), Shri Ram Saran Das Kapur (HUF at Amritsar). Cases transferred ~29-6-1953 or 1954 from ITO A Ward/F Ward Amritsar to ITO Special Circle Amritsar. Notices u/s 34 for 1947-48 to 1951-52 issued.

Sriram Jhabarmull group (Petitions 211-215 of 1956): Nandram Agarwalla, sole proprietor at Kalimpong (branch Calcutta), import/export piece-goods, commission agents, raw wool dealers. Assessments for 1944-45 to 1948-49. Transfers: 15-3-1946 from ITO Jalpaiguri to Central Circle I Calcutta, then to IV, 8-6-1946 back to I, 27-7-1946 by CIT Central Calcutta u/s 5(7A) to Central Circle IV Calcutta. Completed assessments and certificate proceedings u/s 46(2) pre-Constitution.

Raichur group (Petitions 225-229 of 1956): Kalloor Siddanna, commission agent/distributor at Raichur Hyderabad. Assessed under Hyderabad IT Act till 1949-50 by Addl ITO Raichur. Post 1-4-1950 under Indian IT Act. On 21-12-1953 CIT Hyderabad transferred u/s 5(7A) to ITO Special Circle Hyderabad. Notices u/s 22(4), assessments 21-3-1955, 24-4-1955. Application u/s 27. Later ~19-5-1955 transferred back to main ITO Raichur u/s 5(7A) and 64(5)(b).

Section 5(7A) inserted by IT Amendment Act 1940 (XL of 1940) post Bombay HC in Dayaldas Kushiram v. CIT Central. Explanation added by IT Amendment Act 1956 (XXVI of 1956) post this Court's Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India.

Petitioners' cases referred to Income Tax Investigation Commission for evasion (e.g., Pannalal Binjraj concealed >Rs.8 lakhs; Bhagwan Das Sud Sons >Rs.30 lakhs). Post Suraj Mall Mohta and Meenakshi Mills cases, reopened u/s 34(1A), assigned to special circles for quick disposal based on geography and workload.
Inconveniences minimized: Accounts examined at assessee's place (e.g., Sahibganj for Pannalal; Hoshiarpur offered but assessee preferred Ambala).

legal_issues.text: Whether section 5(7A) of the Indian Income-tax Act is ultra vires the Constitution as infringing the fundamental rights enshrined in article 14 and article 19(1)(g).
Whether specific transfer orders are omnibus/wholesale and invalid per Bidi Supply Co., or discriminatory/mala fide.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 5(7A) invests naked arbitrary power to transfer cases without guidelines, time limit, reasons; violates valuable right under s.64(1),(2) to local assessment; discriminatory as picks one assessee vs. others similarly situated; s.64(5) consequential and invalid; infringes Art 14 (substantial discrimination) and Art 19(1)(g) (unreasonable restriction).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art 14, 19(1)(g); s.64(1),(2),(5); Anwar Ali Sarkar; Dwarka Prasad; Himmatlal Harilal Mehta v. State of MP; Bose J. dissent in Bidi Supply

petitioner_arguments.text: Transfer orders omnibus/wholesale unlimited in time, causing harassment (e.g., Calcutta to Delhi/Ambala); no hearing/reasons.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bidi Supply Co. (majority on order, minority on section)

respondent_arguments.text: s.5(7A) for administrative convenience to handle complex cases (widespread activities, evasion); no discriminatory procedure - same assessment process, appeals; s.64 right not absolute, yields to tax collection exigencies; transfers consider assessee convenience (nearest ITO, local hearings); power in high officials, presume bona fides; abuse remedied case-by-case, not invalidate section.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.5(7A),64(5); Explanation 1956; Dayaldas Kushiram; Wallace Bros; Matajog Dobey

respondent_arguments.text: Explanation to s.5(7A) validates omnibus orders covering all pending/future proceedings any year; specific transfers bona fide for workload post Investigation Commission cases.

court_reasoning.text: s.64(1),(2) confers benefit/right to local assessment but not absolute - yields to tax collection exigencies; place of assessment administrative convenience, not jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Exigencies may require transfer for efficient assessment of complex cases.

court_reasoning.text: s.5(7A) power guided by Act's purpose (assessment/collection); discretionary but not arbitrary - for convenience in widespread/inter-related cases; no material discrimination as procedure same post-transfer; minor deviation from s.64 not violate Art 14.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power in top authorities (CBR/CIT), presume proper exercise; inconvenience minimized.

court_reasoning.text: Omnibus orders saved by 1956 Explanation - covers all proceedings pending/commenced post-transfer for any year; no reissue of notices needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Explanation expands 'case' to include all years.

court_reasoning.text: Specific orders not discriminatory: Pre-Constitution orders (Sriram) not challengeable (Art 13 no retrospectivity); Raichur/Amritsar - reverted/same building, acquiesced; others for Investigation Commission backlog/workload, local hearings provided.

holdings.text: Section 5(7A) intra vires, not violative of Art 14 or 19(1)(g); transfer orders valid, not discriminatory/mala fide.
Petitions lack substance; specific groups barred by acquiescence/pre-Constitution actions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Left constitutionality open; struck omnibus order pre-Explanation; minority (Bose J.) held section invalid - distinguished.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Art 14 requires no unguided power enabling discrimination; minor deviations ok.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dayaldas Kushiram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Central
precedents_cited.relevance: Led to s.5(7A); s.64 for local assessment 'as far as practicable'.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dwarka Prasad Laxmi Narain v. State of U.P.
Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay
Wallace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. CIT Bombay

precedents_cited.relevance: Presume no abuse by high officials.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: s.5(7A) empowers transfers for admin convenience; overrides s.64 local assessment; Explanation covers all proceedings.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: No violation by s.5(7A); petitions under Art 32.

outcome.summary: All petitions dismissed holding s.5(7A) constitutional and transfer orders valid/not discriminatory; no substance in challenges; some barred by pre-Constitution actions/acquiescence.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs; one set between respondents in each petition, one set per group.

key_quotes.text: Section 5(7A) of the Act is not violative of article 14 of the Constitution and also does not impose any unreasonable restriction of the fundamental right to carry on trade or business enshrined in article 19(1)(g) of the Constitution.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding upholding validity of section.

key_quotes.text: The power is guided and controlled by the purpose which is to be achieved by the Act itself, viz., the charge of income-tax, the assessment and collection thereof.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains limits on discretion under s.5(7A).

key_quotes.text: If the Legislature itself had done here what the Central Board of Revenue has done... it would, in my judgment, have been bad.
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Bose J. minority view in Bidi Supply relied by petitioners.
